title: 106_s1733
content: The Act is titled the "Electronic Benefit Transfer Interoperability and Portability Act of 2000" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The Act aims to protect the food stamp program's integrity, ensure cost-effective portability of benefits across State borders, enhance interstate commerce involving electronic transactions, and eliminate inefficiencies from State-administered systems. It amends the Food Stamp Act of 1977 to address interoperability and portability of electronic benefit transfer transactions. The subsection defines terms related to electronic benefit transfer transactions, including electronic benefit transfer card, contract, interoperability, and interstate transactions. The subsection defines terms related to electronic benefit transfer transactions, including interstate transaction, portability, settling, and smart card. The term 'smart card' refers to an intelligent benefit card, while 'switching' involves routing interstate transactions electronically. By October 1, 2002, systems for electronic benefit transfer cards must be interoperable and portable across all states without imposing costs on food stamp retailers. The Secretary will establish national standards for interoperability and portability of electronic benefit transfer cards within 210 days. Any new contracts must comply with these standards. Exemptions may apply. The Secretary will establish national standards for interoperability and portability of electronic benefit transfer cards within 210 days. Exemptions may apply to contracts entered into before a specified date and waivers may be granted to State agencies facing technological barriers. The State agency may be granted a waiver for achieving interoperability and portability by October 1, 2002, if facing technological barriers. Smart card systems can comply with requirements after October 1, 2002. The Secretary will determine a technological method for interoperability with electronic benefit transfer cards. The Secretary will fund 100 percent of costs for switching and settling interstate transactions incurred by State agencies, based on adopted standards. SEC. 4. STUDY OF ALTERNATIVES FOR HANDLING ELECTRONIC BENEFIT TRANSACTIONS INVOLVING FOOD STAMP BENEFITS. The Secretary of Agriculture will study and report on options for managing interstate electronic benefit transactions for food stamp benefits, including the possibility of a single hub for switching.
